title: Backend server starts on port 8000
description: The FastAPI backend server should start successfully and listen on port 8000 for incoming HTTP requests.
setup: RUN cd backend && pip install -r requirements.txt
steps: RUN cd backend && uvicorn main:app --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000 &
WAIT 3 seconds for server startup
RUN curl -s -o /dev/null -w '%{http_code}' http://localhost:8000/
VERIFY HTTP response status code is 200 or 404 (server is responding)
expected_outcome: Backend server is running and accepting connections on port 8000.

title: Frontend dev server starts on port 5173
description: The SvelteKit frontend development server should start successfully and listen on port 5173.
setup: RUN cd frontend && npm install
steps: RUN cd frontend && npm run dev -- --port 5173 &
WAIT 5 seconds for dev server startup
RUN curl -s -o /dev/null -w '%{http_code}' http://localhost:5173/
VERIFY HTTP response status code is 200 indicating the dev server is serving content
expected_outcome: Frontend dev server is running and accepting connections on port 5173.

title: Backend health endpoint returns OK
description: The backend should expose a health check endpoint that returns a successful status to confirm the service is operational.
steps: RUN curl -s http://localhost:8000/health
VERIFY response JSON contains a status field with value 'ok' or 'healthy'
VERIFY HTTP response status code is 200
expected_outcome: Health endpoint returns JSON with status 'ok' and HTTP 200.

title: Database auto-creates on startup
description: The SQLite database file should be automatically created when the backend starts for the first time, with all required tables initialized.
steps: RUN ls -la backend/*.db backend/data/*.db 2>/dev/null || ls -la *.db data/*.db 2>/dev/null
VERIFY a .db or .sqlite file exists in the backend directory or data subdirectory
RUN sqlite3 $(find . -name '*.db' -o -name '*.sqlite' | head -1) '.tables'
VERIFY the database contains at least one table related to optimizations
expected_outcome: SQLite database file is auto-created on startup with optimization tables initialized.

title: Frontend serves index HTML page
description: The frontend dev server should serve a valid HTML page at the root URL that bootstraps the SvelteKit application.
steps: RUN curl -s http://localhost:5173/
VERIFY response contains <!DOCTYPE html> or <html
VERIFY response contains a <div id="app"> or SvelteKit mount point
VERIFY response includes <script> tags for JavaScript bundle loading
expected_outcome: Root URL serves valid HTML with SvelteKit application bootstrap code.

title: Backend CORS allows frontend origin
description: The backend should have CORS configured to accept requests from the frontend origin at http://localhost:5173.
steps: RUN curl -s -I -X OPTIONS -H 'Origin: http://localhost:5173' -H 'Access-Control-Request-Method: POST' http://localhost:8000/api/optimize
VERIFY response headers contain Access-Control-Allow-Origin with value http://localhost:5173 or wildcard *
VERIFY response headers contain Access-Control-Allow-Methods including POST
VERIFY HTTP response status is 200 or 204 for the preflight request
expected_outcome: CORS preflight response allows requests from http://localhost:5173 with POST method.

title: API docs available at /docs

SCREENSHOT verify Swagger UI documentation page loads with API endpoint listings
VERIFY page title contains 'Swagger UI' or 'FastAPI'
VERIFY page displays at least one API endpoint path
expected_outcome: Swagger UI documentation page loads at /docs showing all available API endpoints.

RUN curl -s -I http://localhost:8000/api/history

VERIFY response Content-Type header contains text/event-stream
VERIFY response body contains SSE formatted data lines starting with 'data:' or 'event:'
VERIFY HTTP response status is 200
expected_outcome: POST /api/optimize returns an SSE stream with Content-Type text/event-stream and properly formatted SSE data.

title: POST /api/optimize accepts prompt payload

title: POST /api/optimize returns SSE stream
description: The optimization endpoint should return a proper SSE stream with multiple events representing the 3-step pipeline stages: Analyze, Optimize, and Validate.

title: GET /api/history returns paginated list

steps: RUN curl -s http://localhost:8000/api/history
VERIFY response is valid JSON
VERIFY response contains an array of optimization records or a paginated wrapper with items/data field
VERIFY response includes pagination metadata such as total, page, per_page, or has_more
VERIFY each record in the list contains at minimum an id and raw_prompt field
expected_outcome: GET /api/history returns a paginated JSON response containing optimization records with pagination metadata.

title: GET /api/history returns empty list initially
description: When no optimizations have been performed, the history endpoint should return an empty list or array.
setup: RUN sqlite3 $(find . -name '*.db' -o -name '*.sqlite' | head -1) 'DELETE FROM optimizations;' 2>/dev/null || true
steps: RUN curl -s http://localhost:8000/api/history
VERIFY response is valid JSON
VERIFY the items/data array is empty with length 0
VERIFY response total count is 0 or the array length is 0
expected_outcome: GET /api/history returns an empty list when no optimization records exist in the database.

title: GET /api/optimize/{id} returns optimization record
description: Fetching a specific optimization by its ID should return the complete record with all fields populated.
setup: RUN curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"prompt": "Write a haiku about programming"}' http://localhost:8000/api/optimize --max-time 20
steps: RUN curl -s http://localhost:8000/api/history | python3 -c "import sys,json; data=json.load(sys.stdin); items=data if isinstance(data,list) else data.get('items',data.get('data',[])); print(items[0]['id'] if items else 'none')"
RUN curl -s http://localhost:8000/api/optimize/{captured_id}
VERIFY response status is 200
VERIFY response JSON contains the full optimization record with id, raw_prompt, optimized_prompt, and status fields
VERIFY the raw_prompt field matches 'Write a haiku about programming'
expected_outcome: GET /api/optimize/{id} returns the complete optimization record matching the requested ID.

VERIFY HTTP response status is 200 or 204

VERIFY the deleted record returns 404 when fetched by ID

title: GET /api/history/stats returns statistics

steps: RUN curl -s http://localhost:8000/api/history/stats

VERIFY response is valid JSON

title: POST /api/optimize/{id}/retry re-runs optimization
description: The retry endpoint should re-run the optimization pipeline for an existing record, creating a new SSE stream with updated results.

RUN curl -s -X POST http://localhost:8000/api/optimize/{captured_id}/retry --max-time 30
VERIFY response status is 200
VERIFY response contains SSE stream data or a new optimization result
RUN curl -s http://localhost:8000/api/optimize/{captured_id}
VERIFY the record has been updated with new optimization results
expected_outcome: POST /api/optimize/{id}/retry re-runs the optimization pipeline and updates the existing record with fresh results.

title: History pagination works with page parameter
description: The history endpoint should support a 'page' query parameter to navigate between pages of results.
setup: RUN for i in $(seq 1 5); do curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d "{\"prompt\": \"Pagination test prompt $i\"}" http://localhost:8000/api/optimize --max-time 15; done
steps: RUN curl -s 'http://localhost:8000/api/history?page=1&per_page=2'
VERIFY response contains at most 2 records in the items array
RUN curl -s 'http://localhost:8000/api/history?page=2&per_page=2'
VERIFY response contains the next set of records different from page 1
VERIFY pagination metadata reflects the correct current page number
expected_outcome: History endpoint correctly paginates results based on the page query parameter.

title: History pagination works with per_page parameter

setup: RUN for i in $(seq 1 5); do curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d "{\"prompt\": \"Per page test prompt $i\"}" http://localhost:8000/api/optimize --max-time 15; done

RUN curl -s 'http://localhost:8000/api/history?per_page=10'
VERIFY response contains up to 10 records
expected_outcome: History endpoint returns the correct number of records as specified by per_page parameter.

title: History search filters by prompt text
description: The history endpoint should support a search/query parameter that filters optimization records by matching against the raw prompt text.
setup: RUN curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"prompt": "Unique zebra striping algorithm implementation"}' http://localhost:8000/api/optimize --max-time 20
RUN curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"prompt": "Simple hello world example"}' http://localhost:8000/api/optimize --max-time 20

VERIFY response contains records where raw_prompt includes the word 'zebra'
VERIFY response does not contain the 'hello world' record
RUN curl -s 'http://localhost:8000/api/history?search=nonexistent_xyz_term'
VERIFY response contains 0 records for a term that does not match any prompt
expected_outcome: History search parameter correctly filters records by matching prompt text content.

title: History sort by created_at works
description: The history endpoint should support sorting results by the created_at timestamp field.
setup: RUN curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"prompt": "First chronological prompt"}' http://localhost:8000/api/optimize --max-time 15
RUN sleep 1
RUN curl -s -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"prompt": "Second chronological prompt"}' http://localhost:8000/api/optimize --max-time 15

VERIFY the first record has a later created_at timestamp than the last record
expected_outcome: History results are correctly sorted by created_at timestamp in both ascending and descending order.

title: History sort order desc/asc works

RUN curl -s 'http://localhost:8000/api/history?order=asc'

VERIFY the order of records is reversed between the two requests
expected_outcome: History endpoint correctly applies desc and asc sort order to results.

steps: RUN three concurrent HTTP POST requests to http://localhost:8000/api/optimize with different prompts: (1) 'Write a sorting algorithm', (2) 'Create a marketing email', (3) 'Design a database schema'
WAIT for all three requests to complete (or timeout after 60 seconds)
VERIFY all three requests complete without HTTP 500 errors
VERIFY each response contains a unique optimization ID
VERIFY the optimized prompt in response 1 relates to sorting algorithms, not marketing or databases
VERIFY the optimized prompt in response 2 relates to marketing emails, not sorting or databases
VERIFY the optimized prompt in response 3 relates to database schemas, not sorting or marketing
RUN a GET request to http://localhost:8000/api/history
VERIFY all three new optimizations appear in the history
expected_outcome: Three concurrent optimization requests all complete successfully with correct, non-mixed results, and all three are persisted in the database without data corruption.

title: Database handles concurrent writes safely
description: Verify that the SQLite database handles concurrent write operations (from simultaneous optimizations, deletions, and tag updates) without corruption or lock errors surfacing to users.
setup: Backend server running on port 8000
steps: RUN MCP tool call: promptforge_optimize with input {"prompt": "Concurrent write test A"} and capture 'id' as id_A
RUN MCP tool call: promptforge_optimize with input {"prompt": "Concurrent write test B"} and capture 'id' as id_B

RUN concurrently: (1) promptforge_tag with input {"optimization_id": "<id_A>", "add_tags": ["concurrent"]}, (2) promptforge_tag with input {"optimization_id": "<id_B>", "add_tags": ["concurrent"]}, (3) promptforge_optimize with input {"prompt": "Concurrent write test C"}
VERIFY all three concurrent operations complete without 'database is locked' errors
VERIFY all three operations produce correct results
RUN MCP tool call: promptforge_get with input {"optimization_id": "<id_A>"}
VERIFY id_A has the 'concurrent' tag applied
RUN MCP tool call: promptforge_get with input {"optimization_id": "<id_B>"}
VERIFY id_B has the 'concurrent' tag applied
RUN MCP tool call: promptforge_stats with input {}
VERIFY the stats reflect all three optimizations in the total count
expected_outcome: Concurrent database write operations (optimizations, tag updates) all complete successfully without 'database is locked' errors, data corruption, or lost writes.
